org.codemonkey.swiftsocketclient
Class ServerHandler

java.lang.Object
  org.codemonkey.swiftsocketclient.ServerHandler
All Implemented Interfaces:
Runnable
public class ServerHandler
extends Object
implements Runnable

Worker thread for the client server that is dedicated to the singular server.

Sets up a child thread that listens for server input, while sending Pong response messages if required and handling messages sent to the server.

Since:
1.0
Author:
Benny Bottema
See Also:
SwiftSocketClient, pong()

Method Detail

sendMessage

public void sendMessage(ClientMessageToServer message)
Logs and sends a message to the server using serverContext, delegating the actual sending to sendResponse(ServerContext, int, ClientMessageToServer), unless the client has said 'Bye Bye' in which case the message to be sent is ignored altogether.

Parameters:
message - The client message to send to the server.
See Also:
ServerContext.isServerSaidByeBye(), sendResponse(ServerContext, int, ClientMessageToServer)

getServerContext

public ServerContext getServerContext()
Returns:
The serverContext containing session data for external use.

pong

public void pong()
Called by ServerMessageToClientPingPong.execute(ServerHandler). Sends a ClientMessageToServerPingPong to the server using sendMessage(ClientMessageToServer).

run

public void run()
Listens to client and converts input to objects of type ServerMessageToClient. Waits for input on the server ServerEndpoint. A thread is being used for this, since reading input is blocking, meaning the thread 'sleeps' while waiting for input. These messages are then added to the server stack for execution by external user.
Note: some messages are filtered by the server as they are of server level, such as ping messages.

Reuses fields from ServerHandler, such as client and serverContext. Keeps listening for input while the server is still running and the server hasn't dropped the connection.

The input data is read per line, so messages need to end with a newline character '\n'. Since clients need to conform to the lowest common denominator, they are required to append a zero (0) byte '\0' as per Flash clients. This character is appended to the newline '\n' character and needs to be discarded manually using a BufferedReader.read().

Each complete line received serves as a datagram and is handled by handleMessage(String).

Specified by:
run in interface Runnable
See Also:
handleMessage(String), SwiftSocketClient.isRunning()

handleMessage

public void handleMessage(String datagramMessage)
Handles a single server message string. Creates a ServerMessageToClient and adds this to the client message queue unless it is a server level message, such as a 'pong' notification, in which case the message is executed directly.

Parameters:
datagramMessage - The client message string, minus newline character '\n' and zero (0) byte '\0'.
See Also:
createDecodedExecutableResponse(String), SwiftSocketClient.addServerResponse(ServerMessageToClient)

createDecodedExecutableResponse

protected ServerMessageToClient<?> createDecodedExecutableResponse(String datagramMessage)
Parses the raw server message into a message id and message content. Passes both values to createDecodedExecutableMessage(int, String) and returns the result. The first 3 bytes of the raw message denote the message code.

In case anything goes wrong, a ServerMessageToClientInvalid object is returned instead which generates some useful message for logging purposes. The server user can choose to filter out unknown messages at its own discretion. If a ServerMessageToClientInvalid is executed however, it will throw a runtime exception with the original message.

Parameters:
datagramMessage - The server input string that represents a single message.
Returns:
createDecodedExecutableMessage(int, String)
See Also:
createInvalidMessage(String, Exception, String)
